content: "http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2009/05/20/budget_crunch_curtails_a_cherished_tradition/" quote: Flags fluttering, fathers hoisting their children on their shoulders, Memorial Day parades are sweet, sad slices of American life, binding communities in somber remembrance. And for decades, Brockton veterans, joined by Scouts and several marching bands, have paraded through city streets in tribute. But not this year. Facing a budget shortfall, a city veterans group that sponsors the parade has canceled the event, sparking anger and finger-pointing among veterans and local officials. The controversy, surfacing less than a week before Monday's holiday, stunned residents who cherished the annual procession, which in wartime has taken on deeper poignance. "To me, this is a slap in the face to all veterans," said Frank Pagliuca, an 83-year-old World War II veteran who has long participated in the parade. "I'm thoroughly disgusted with the city. Are we going to forget all the people we left overseas? This is a day to remember." Moises Rodrigues, the city's director of community services, said the mayor's office learned only last week that the Veterans Council could not finance the event. The cancellation was reported yesterday in the Brockton Enterprise. If the city had found out earlier, Rodrigues said, officials might have been able to save the event with private donations... Memorial Day parades have lost some of their luster in recent years, becoming smaller and more subdued. The ranks of the World War II generation are dwindling, and many families take advantage of the three-day weekend, the symbolic start of summer, to leave town... Turning over the soil in front of his brother's grave, Kenneth Galligan said Memorial Day used to be a sacred day of remembrance. Now, it's a 20-percent-off commercial bonanza.

content: The cancellation of the Boston Memorial Day Parade due to lack of money (respect?) is indicative of a much larger (and disturbing) trend. The fact that we are at war today is a fact that, somehow, many have seemed to have forgotten. War today doesn't have the same impact on civilians it once did. The Civil War, WWI and WWII required some sacrifice on the part of civilian populations (rationing, shortages, etc), which served as an ever-present reminder of the sacrifices being made by our warriors. In our technoworld of today, with information available instantaneously, it seems most couldn't care less. Rather than being bitter. Us veterans should realize, as Winston Churchill said of the RAF during WWII: "Never have so many owed so much to so few!"
